Administration Guide

Overview of the Administration section in Unit Master, including system modules, roles, control categories and system monitoring tools.

What is the Administration Section?

The Administration area is where system administrators configure how Unit Master works. From here you can manage system modules, user roles, access controls, and monitor key system activities such as login activity, audits, error logs and bulk communications.

This guide explains each item in the Administration menu and what it is used for.

1. System Modules

The System Modules section contains the main menus of Unit Master. Here administrators can:

  • Add a new module name
  • Edit an existing module
  • Delete modules that are no longer needed

This allows you to control the overall structure of the system and which functional areas are available to users.

2. Roles

Roles define permissions and responsibilities assigned to users in the system. Each role controls what a user can see and do inside Unit Master.

There are two main actions in this section:

  • Assign menus / sub menus
    Opens a form where you choose which main modules and menus a role is allowed to see.
  • Custom permissions
    This is typically accessed via a blue button and allows the administrator to define specific actions each role is authorised to perform (for example create, edit, approve, delete).

By configuring roles correctly, you ensure that users only access the parts of the system that match their responsibilities.

3. Control Categories

Control Categories help the system administrator manage what different users can see, do, or access inside Unit Master.

These settings define control groups or categories that can be linked to clients or users. Once configured and assigned to a new client, they typically do not change.

This ensures consistent access behaviour and standardised control rules across the system.

4. User Login Activity

The User Login Activity section tracks login details for users. It records key information such as:

  • Login date and time
  • Which user logged in
  • Sometimes the location or device used, depending on configuration

This log helps administrators monitor access, detect unusual activity and support audits or security reviews.

5. Company

The Company section stores general details about the organisation using Unit Master. Typical information includes:

  • Company or organisation name
  • Registration and contact details
  • Address and other general information

Keeping this information up to date ensures that statements, reports and communications show the correct company details.

6. User Audit

The User Audit tracks actions performed inside the system. It helps answer questions such as:

  • Who changed a record?
  • What was updated or deleted?
  • When did the change happen?

This is essential for accountability, compliance and internal control.

7. Communication Templates

Communication Templates are used to set up standard messages that can be sent to clients. Examples include:

  • Welcome messages
  • Transaction confirmations
  • Monthly or quarterly statements notifications

Templates help keep communication consistent and save time when sending the same type of message to many clients.

8. Error Logs

Error Logs capture technical issues that occur while the system is running. When the system fails or encounters an error, information is saved in the database or a log file.

These logs typically store:

  • Error type and message
  • Date and time of the error
  • Technical details to help developers diagnose the issue

Administrators and support teams use error logs to troubleshoot problems and improve stability.

9. Bulk Emails

The Bulk Emails section is used to send emails to many clients at once. Typical uses include:

  • Announcements or updates
  • Campaigns or product information
  • Important notices or reminders

Bulk email tools save time and ensure consistent messages reach all relevant clients.
